oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aquaplaning
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: camps; recreation; 1910s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Camper skiing on the lake. -- Text on front: 57 -- [According to Watersportsindia.com, waterskiing first appeared in the early 1900s. At the time, it was called "aquaplaning." Aquaplane boards were usually 6 to 10 feet long and 3 feet wide, with a rope tied to the front. The skier or aquaplaner held on to a rope which was attached to the front of the board. This made it possible to stand up and use body weight to manipulate the board.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Honorable Isham G. Harris
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Harris, Isham G.; portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Caption: Hon. Isham G. Harris -- Bureau, Engraving & Printing. -- Text on separate paper: Copied from the Courier Journal - Of all the men in the South in 1861 Isham G. Harris was best fitted for President of the Confederacy. Had he been chosen, history might have been very different. He would have been the Carnot of America. But the hand of God was in that mighty conflict, it seems that the battle was to the South, the champion to the North, but a montmorency like Harris might have changed the result. -- Henry Watterson, editor -- Courier Journal-
